awd_titl_txt: CIF:Small:Machine Learning Based Turbo Detection for Two and Three Dimensional Magnetic Recording
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates two and three dimensional magnetic recording (TDMR and 3DMR) for next generation hard disk drives. In TDMR, bits are written on two-dimensional patches of a magnetic storage disk, whereas in 3DMR bits are written on multiple disk layers. TDMR is an emerging technology that promises up to an order of magnitude increase in information bits per unit of disk area, without requiring radical redesign of the disk. 3DMR is an even newer technology that has the promise of significant areal information density increases over TDMR. A key problem in TDMR and 3DMR is that, at high densities, some bits are not written to any of the magnetic grains on the disk. Moreover, one must contend with signal dispersion: along-track, across-tracks, and between layers. This project investigates machine learning for turbo detection of TDMR and 3DMR channels at high densities of between 1 and 4 magnetic grains per coded bit. The considered machine learning topics include design of local area influence probabilistic model detectors, recently introduced by the investigators, and design of deep neural network detectors for TDMR and 3DMR. Through established collaborations, the investigators will validate the developed techniques with realistic waveforms and will facilitate technology transfer. The project also includes educational and outreach components. The investigators will work with the Voiland College of Engineering Diversity Programs office to identify potential undergraduate researchers from underrepresented groups to participate in the project.

The specific technical objectives of this project are: (i) developing information-theoretic design techniques for deep neural networks, (ii) designing machine learning based media noise predictors for TDMR turbo-detectors, (iii) designing deep neural network detectors that handle both two-dimensional intersymbol interference and media noise, (iv) generalizing the machine learning based detector designs for 3DMR, and (v) evaluating the developed designs with TDMR and 3DMR waveforms derived from realistic micromagnetic simulations, obtained from international collaborators. This work is expected to provide significant progress toward the industry's information density target of 10 Terabits per square inch.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Since the introduction of hard disk drives (HDDs) in 1957, the information areal density (IAD) has increased from 2000 bits/in2 to more than 1 trillion bits (1 Terabit) per in2. Modern HDDs store bits as positive or negative magnetizations of magnetic grains oriented perpendicular to the disk surface and support an IAD of more than 1 Terabit/in2, with about 10 magnetic grains per bit. In recent years, increasing the IAD by shrinking the average grain size has run up against the superparamagnetic limit in which random thermal variations flip grain magnetizations, thereby limiting the stored information's longevity.

The superparamagnetic limit has spurred research on new technologies for increasing HDD IADs. Most HDDs write data-bits on each track independently. The track-pitch (TP), i.e., the track center-to-center distance, must be large enough to reduce intertrack interference (ITI), which occurs when the read head picks up magnetic signals from adjacent tracks, to an acceptable level. Down-track intersymbol interference (ISI) is reduced by using the Viterbi algorithm (VA) on the state trellis defined by the downtrack interference between the bits.

Two dimensional magnetic recording (TDMR), proposed in 2009, increases density by decreasing the TP and writing and reading bits in several tracks simultaneously. In TDMR, the readback system must deal with both down-track ISI and cross-track ITI. The higher data density reduces the number of grains per bit. This reduces the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), and also causes further degradation from interactions between data on the closely-spaced tracks. These interactions include nonlinear signal distortion and complex magnetostatic interactions that increase signal-dependent media noise. Trellis-based detection methods have been proposed for TDMR, but most suffer from an explosion in the number of trellis states when more than two tracks are read simultaneously. Also, previously proposed media noise modeling methods are limited in their ability to accurately model highly non-linear media noise.

The objective of this project was to investigate machine learning (MnL) techniques for iterative detection of two- and three-dimensional magnetic recording    channels at densities of between 1 and 4 magnetic grains per coded bit, in order to progress toward the HDD industry's IAD target of 10 Terabits/in2. Specific goals included: 1. Design deep neural network (DNN) based media noise predictors for TDMR turbo-detectors; 2. Design DNN detectors that handle ISI, ITI and media noise; 3. Generalize the MnL based detector designs for multi-layer magnetic recording (MLMR), an emerging HDD technology that has upper and lower magnetic layers; 4. Evaluate the developed designs with TDMR and MLMR read-head waveforms obtained from our international collaborators; these waveforms are derived from realistic micromagnetic simulations using a computationally efficient grain-flipping-probabilistic (GFP) technique.

The project investigated a number of novel signal processing architectures that incorporate deep neural networks (DNNs) into TDMR. Among the most successful outcomes of this work, described in several publications and in one U.S. patent, is a "trellis-CNN" system that separates the TDMR signal processing into two functions: a multi-track trellis processor for ISI/ITI equalization, and a convolutional neural network (CNN) for media noise prediction.  These two functions exchange messages iteratively with each other and with an error control decoder in a "turbo detection" process that results in lower bit error rates (BERs).  Separating these two functions avoids the trellis state explosion problem. Furthermore, the CNN media noise predictor can more accurately model the non-linear  media noise, compared to existing state-of-the-art. This system achieved an IAD of 3.877 Terabits/in2 on 11.4 Teragrains/in2 grain flipping probabilistic (GFP) data, which is among the highest reported IADs to date on realistic GFP-simulated HDD waveforms at grain densities representative of current-generation HDDs.  The project also investigated and produced publications on other TDMR signal processing architectures wherein a single DNN handles both ISI/ITI equalization and media noise prediction; these systems achieve IADs close to that of the trellis-CNN system, but require significantly more computational complexity. 

The project also investigated multi-layer magnetic recording (MLMR). MLMR requires joint signal separation and equalization: the readers lie just above the disk surface and hence receive a superposition of signals from the upper and lower layers, and the received signal now suffers from 3D-ISI due to per layer ITI and downtrack ISI, plus inter-layer inference (ILI). We published several papers on CNN-based signal processing architectures that successfully solve this joint separation and equalization problem, and achieve higher IADs compared to single-layer TDMR systems. These publications are among the first to show MLMR density gains on realistic GFP-simulated MLMR waveforms at grain densities representative of current-generation HDDs.  The signal separation and signal-dependent noise estimation problems addressed in our MLMR and TDMR work on this project are similar to those found in non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) techniques proposed for increasing the data throughput of next generation (6G) wireless systems. We are currently preparing publications that show how CNN-based signal processing can greatly benefit certain classes of NOMA systems.
